Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Situation2: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Story:
My phone buzzed with two messages at once. My younger brother, Sam, texted, “Can you come over? I really need to talk.” He never asked for help unless he was truly upset. At the same time, my boyfriend, Alex, messaged, “Can we talk? I’m confused about our plans this weekend.” I could sense the tension in his words; we’d just had a small disagreement about whether to spend Saturday with his friends or mine.

I stared at the screen, feeling my chest tighten. Sam had always counted on me to be there when things got rough at home, and I’d promised myself I’d never let him down. But Alex expected me to work through issues together, not leave things hanging. I knew if I didn’t respond soon, he’d feel ignored, maybe even hurt. Both needed me, both right now, and I felt pulled in two directions—torn between being the reliable sister and the understanding girlfriend. My mind raced, guilt and worry swirling as I tried to figure out who needed me more, and what I was supposed to do next.
